poem:
**On the Subject of Slippers**

He steps onto the grass,  
morning dew kissing terry cloth,  
carries half the garden inside—  
a tiny jungle in each thread.  
Yet in the secret comfort, soft rebellion thrives,  
where rooms yield to careless footprints,  
and the world outside surrenders  
to the cozy persistence of wool.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "You be the judge: should my husband stop wearing his slippers outside the house? The prosecution: Mindy He’ll wear them in the garden and then drag all these bits of mud on his soles into our home I believe that slippers should only be worn in soft spaces: the bedroom, around the house, maybe the bathroom if the floor isn’t wet. But they are most definitely not meant for doing odd jobs outside or stepping". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
